items.text: Your world is the magical land of Legend. In Legend there are many kinds of adventurer, each with unique skills and techniques for dealing with creatures of the supernatural. Those who rely on a good sword and the strength of their right arm are called Warriors. The practitioners of the magical arts are called Enchanters, with many deadly spells always ready at their fingertips. Sages are a class of ascetic monks, wise in ancient lore but also skillful in the use of quarterstaff, bow and the unarmed martial arts. Lastly there are the Tricksters; they are swift and dextrous swordsmen, but their true forte is the use of stealth, guile and cunning.

Blood Sword can be played solo or in a party of up to four characters. Each character is an alter ego in the fantasy world of Legend. Characters have a rank that indicates how experienced and powerful they are. The fewer the number of characters in the party, the higher their starting rank:
number of characters    composition of party

one                     a single 8th rank character
two                     two characters of 4th rank
three                   three characters of 3rd rank
four                    four characters of 2nd rank

Each character belongs to one of the four character types:

The Warrior believes that strength, courage and nobility of purpose are sufficient to achieve any goal.

The Enchanter is able to alter reality by casting magic spells.

The Sage, a learned ascetic, constantly seeks to hone the powers of the human mind.

The Trickster is a clever and dashing figure with an eye for the main chance.

If there is more than one character in the party, they must be of different character types.
Dice rolls used in the game are expressed in this format:

meaning that x dice are rolled and y is added to the total.

For example, 3D6+1 means rolling three dice and adding 1 to the total, giving a number from 4 to 19. Another example: 1D6-2 means rolling one die and subtracting two. Negative numbers count as zero unless otherwise stated, so this would give a score from 0 to 4.
Each character is described by four attributes. These are:
This is a measure of how skilled and powerful a fighter the character is.
This is an indicator of the character's resistance to hostile spells and, in the case of an Enchanter, his or her aptitude for magic.
This encompasses quickness of thought, dexterity and wits.

This attribute measures the character's state of health. Wounds are deducted from Endurance, and if it reaches zero then the character dies. Healing spells and potions can increase Endurance, but never higher than your score at the start of the adventure.

It is only possible to fight an opponent in an orthogonally adjacent square (not across a diagonal) and you cannot move on to a square already occupied by another character. You cannot move where there are no squares, nor on to a blacked-out square, which represents an obstacle such as a pillar or a large statue.

Shaded squares can be moved through by opponents but not by players. For example, in the map to the left, the shaded squares indicate a bed of coals which the opponents are immune to.

Unless otherwise stated, an opponent will always move to attack the nearest player. If several adventurers are equidistant from the opponent, it will attack the player based on some other criteria, e.g. low Endurance, preferred target, etc.

The opponent will sometimes give chase, and if they catch up with you then their Endurance will reflect how many wounds you've already inflicted.

Combat takes place in rounds. Each round, every character gets the opportunity to perform one action: to attack, cast a spell, and so on.

Actions are taken in sequence based on each combatant's Awareness score. The combatant with the highest Awareness acts first, then the combatant with the next highest Awareness, and so on. A combatant who is killed (reduced to 0 Endurance) before his turn does not get to act.

A character can choose any one option for which he or she is eligible as his or her action for the round:

You can move to any square on the tactical map. However, you cannot move through or end your move on a square already occupied by another character. There are no diagonal moves. If you begin a round adjacent to an opponent, you can only move away if you chose the defend option last round.
Strike at any opponent who is in a square adjacent to yours (linearly, not diagonally). To hit your opponent you must roll equal to or less than your Fighting Prowess on two dice.
This makes you harder to hit. For one full round (i.e. until your turn next round) any opponent trying to hit you must roll three dice instead of the usual two.

You can shot an arrow at one opponent anywhere on the tactical map except in a square directly adjacent to yours. This is an option for Sages and Tricksters only; for more information, see the special rules for those character types.

In order to flee, a player must start the round either on an exit square or adjacent to another player who is on or adjacent to the exit square(s) The party only flees successfully if all players agree to flee. The entire party flees on the turn of the slowest player (i.e. lowest Awareness)

(Enchanters only.) The Enchanter prepares a spell for casting in the following or subsequent rounds. Calling a spell to mind can be done at any time (not just in combat) and the spell held in readiness indefinitely. Multiple different spells can be held in mind, but each spell held temporarily reduces the Enchanter's Psychic Ability by 1.
(Enchanters only.) The Enchanter must previously have called the spell to mind in order to cast it. The rules for spell casting are in the Enchanter's special section.

When striking at an opponent (i.e., when you choose the fight option for a round), you roll 2D6. A score of equal to or lower than your Fighting Prowess means that your blow has hit. If you hit, you roll damage dice to see how much of an Endurace loss you have inflicted. The amount depends on your character type and rank -- see special rulles for the character.
If your opponent has armour, reduce your dice roll for damage by their Armour Rating score, and the result (if greater than zero) is deducted from the opponent's Endurance.

You have a Fighting Prowess of 7 and a damage roll of 1D6+1. You are attacking a troll whose Fighting Prowess is 6 and which rolls for 1D6 for damage. You have the higher Awareness, so you get first blow. Rolling two dice, you score a 3; this is under your Fighting Prowess score, so you have succeeded in hitting the troll. Next you rolle one die and add 1 for the dmage your blow inflicts. You roll a 6, which with +1 gives 7, but the troll has an Armour Rating of 2, so only 5 points are deducted from its Endurance.

If still alive (i.e. above 0 Endurance) the troll now gets to hack back at you. It rolls on two dice -- exactly equal to its Fighting Prowess, so good enough to hit you, though only just. For its damage die roll it scores a 1; because you have an Armour Rating of 2 this means that you lose no Endurance. The troll's claws hit you, but scrape harmlessly off your studded leather jerkin. The battle rages on for another round.

If you choose the defend option then your opponent must roll equal to or under his Fighting Prowess on three dice in order to hit you. You do not get to strike a blow yourself in the round you are defending.

You will start your adventure with a suit of armour. This gives an Armour rating of 3 if you're a Warrior, or of 2 if you belong to one of the other character types.

Your armour protects you in combat by absorbing its Armour Rating from any damage you would otherwise take. For instance, if a monster rolls 2D6+1 for damage and gets a total of 13, that is the number of Endurance points you would lose if your were unarmoured. If you are wearing armour with an Armour Rating of 2, you would take only 11 (i.e., 13 minus 2) points of damage.

You cannot wear two suits of armour at once in order to combine their Armour Ratings.

If an opponent's Armour Rating is not given, it is 0.

If you lose your weapon, reduce your Fighting Prowess and damage dice rolls by 2 until you acquire a new one. For example, an 8th rank Sage normally has a Fighting Prowess of 8 and rolls 3D6 damage. If the Sage were to lose his or her sword and be forced to fight barehanded, he or she would temporarily have a Fighting Prowess of 6 and roll 3D6-2 for damage.

You are limited to carrying up to ten items per player. If you are carrying ten items and find another item you want, you must discard one of the items you're already carrying or give it to another player in order to make space for it in your backpack.

Your money pouch counts as one item, regardless of how much money is in it.

A quiver (available to Sages and Tricksters) will hold up to six arrows and counts as one item. That is if you have a quiver containing six arrows then it still only counts as one item and not as seven.

Magic is the special province of Enchanters and Sages. The way in which magic works for those classes is fully set out in their special sections, but every adventurer needs to be aware that there are two types of magic spell:

Blasting spells simply inflic damage, and if you happen to be the target there is not much you can do about it. You deduct the spell's damage (less your Armour Rating) from your Endurance score. A fireball is an example of a blasting spell.

Psychic spells can be resisted by rolling equal to or less than your Psychic Ability score on two dice. If you make the resistance roll, the spell fails to work against you. A hex is an example of a psychic spell.
The type of spell will always be indicated whether it is of the psychic or blasting variety.

Experience points are a measure of a character's skill and power. If you survive the Battlepits, you will be awarded a number of experience points to be divided among all surviving characters. You also tally in any special bonus awards (or penalties) you were given during the adventure. The total experience points a character accumulates will enable him or her to rise in rank.

You start the adventure with the base level experience points required for your rank: 250 if you are 2nd rank, 500 if you are 3rd, etc. If you play through the adventure with a single (8th-rank) character and receive an award of 1000 experience, for example, then you will advance to 12th rank. If you had the same award as a party of four 2nd-rank characters, each would advance to 3rd rank.
The following four sections provide detailed rules for each character type

You are a master of the fighting arts. You have better Fighting Prowess than any other character type, and when you strike a blow you inflict more damage. You also have chainmail armour which provides an Armour Rating of 3, which is better than the armour available to other characters.

Thee advantages give you a real edge in any fight, but you do not get things all your own way. You have none of the other characters' special skills -- the Sage's ESP, for instance, or the Trickster's low devious cunning. Also, because you follow the honourable traditions of your class, you must be careful to stay true to the code of chivalry.
Your attributes at various ranks are:

The money pouch contains 10 gold pieces if you're 2nd rank, 15 gold pieces if you're 3rd rank, 20 gold pieces if you're 4th rank, and 40 gold pieces if you're 8th rank. Regardless of its contents, the pouch still counts as one item for encumbrance purposes.

Some adventurers are honourable and prefer to face their foes in a straight fight. You live by your wits. If you can win by trickery or by shooting someone in the back, you will. You know how to wield a sword if you have to, but your main weapon is cunning.
Your attributes at various ranks are:

The money pouch contains 10 gold pieces if you're 2nd rank, 15 gold pieces if you're 3rd rank, 20 gold pieces if you're 4th rank, and 40 gold pieces if you're 8th rank. Regardless of its contents, the pouch counts as one item against the limit of ten item you can carry. The quiver contains six arrows at the start of the adventure.

Two special rules apply to a Trickster:

As long as you have your bow and arrows, you can use the shoot option. You do not have to be in an adjacent square to you opponent in order to shoot. A shoot roll is just like a fight roll: to hit you must roll equal to or less than your Fighting Prowess on two dice.

Regardless of your rank, arrows inflict only 1D6 Endurance damage on the target. The target's Armour Rating subtracts from this as usual.

Your agility makes you good at evading attacks. When an opponent makes a fight roll against you, they must roll their Fighting Prowess or less on 2D6+1 to hit you, rather than the usual 2D6. If you choose the defend action, the opponent must roll to hit you on 3D6+1.

Your upbringing has been in the spartan Monastery of Illumination on the barren island of Kaxos. There you studied the Mystic Way, a series of demanding spiritual disciplines combined with rigorous physical training.
Your attributes at various ranks are:

The money pouch contains 10 gold pieces if you're 2nd rank, 15 gold pieces if you're 3rd rank, 20 gold pieces if you're 4th rank, and 40 gold pieces if you're 8th rank. Regardless of its contents, the pouch counts as one item against the limit of ten item you can carry. The quiver contains six arrows at the start of the adventure.

Some special rules apply to a Trickster:

As long as you have your bow and arrows, you can use the shoot option. You do not have to be in an adjacent square to you opponent in order to shoot. A shoot roll is just like a fight roll: to hit you must roll equal to or less than your Fighting Prowess on two dice.

Regardless of your rank, arrows inflict only 1D6 Endurance damage on the target. The target's Armour Rating subtracts from this as usual.

Your expertise in quarterstaff fighting gives you a knowledge of critical nerve points. When attacking with the staff, you have the option to make your fight roll on three dice instead of two. This is more difficult, but it means that if you do hit you inflict an extra 1D6 damage and knock your foe off blance, casing him to take his next action at the end of the round (i.e. as if he had an Awareness score of 1).

You can use this ability once each time you turn to a new option, except when the section you've turned to involves a combat. When you attempt to heal, decide how many points of Endurance you are going to use. Deduct these from your Endurance, then roll 1D6-2 and multiply the score by the number of Endurance you expended. The result is the healing energy, in the form of Endurance points, that you are able to draw from the cosmic flux. Distribute the points however you choose among the players.

For example, say you expend 5 Endurance in a healing attempt. You roll 1D6-2, scoring 3. So you get 15 Endurance points. You can restore your own Endurance to what is was before you tried the healing, and still have 10 points to distribute to your comrades.

It is not possible to heal a character whose Endurance is at 0 or less. They are dead, and it is beyond your power to restore them.
Your other special powers will be explained in situations where you might need them. They include:
This is the ability to detect thoughts.
This is the ability to see through materials such as curtains, fog or water -- though not store or metal.
This is the ability to negate the force of gravity on your body, allowing you to rise vertically into the air.
This is the ability to dispel ghosts and other wraiths by stifling the paranormal energies that sustain them.
Forget the mundane arts of swordplay. You know that true power lies in the manipulation of occult powers of sorcery.
Your attributes at various ranks are:

The money pouch contains 10 gold pieces if you're 2nd rank, 15 gold pieces if you're 3rd rank, 20 gold pieces if you're 4th rank, and 40 gold pieces if you're 8th rank. Regardless of its contents, the pouch counts as one item against the limit of ten item you can carry.
Your special skills are more involved than those of other characters because you have a host of useful and deadly spells at your command:

Before you can cast a spell, you must call it to mind. If done during combat, this is an action and takes one round.

You can call spells to mind at any time, and keep them in mind without effort, so you may wish to have a few ready before encountering an enemy -- rather like having a cocked and loaded crossbow.

But there's a drawback: each spell that you have in mind temporarily reduces your Psychic Ability by 1 until it is cast. If you keep several spells in mind at all times, you will therefore be adventuring with a depleted Psychic Ability, and this makes you more vulnerable to psychic attacks.

The attempt to cast a spell is an action ad takes one round. It does not happen automatically: in order to cast a spell successfully, you must roll equal or less than your Psychic Ability on 2D6. Add the Complexity Level of the spell to the dice roll. If you fail to cast the spell, you can try again the next round; this time the roll is easier, as you subtract 1 from the roll. If you fail again, you subtract 2 from your roll on the next round.

If the spell-casting process is interrupted (e.g., you take a round out to defend or fight) then you have to go back to rolling 2D6 plus the spell's full Complexity Level.

You have a Psychic Ability of 9. You have called two spells into mind in case of trouble, so your current Psychic Ability is 7. In an encounter with several hobgoblins, you first try casting a Sheet Lightning spell. This is a Complexity Level Four spell, so on the first round you need to roll 7 or less on 2D6+4. You fail that but continue trying the next round, this time needing to make 7 or less on 2D6+3. You fail again, so on the third round you are rolling 2D6+2. This time you succeed: a crackling bolt blasts the hobgoblins.
Once you have succeeded in casting a spell, it is no longer held in your mind. If you want to cast it a second time in the same battle, you must first call it to mind again.
All your spells except for Ghastly Touch are ranged. That is, you do not have to be in an adjacent square to your opponent in order to cast the spell at them.
The combat spells available to you are:

Complexity Level One

Causes all enemies to lose 1D6 Endurance. This is a Blasting spell, so it cannot be resisted. The enemies' Armour Rating (if any) is deducted from the damage die roll.
